Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2012 05:12PM MadisoninMd wrote: I did chemo first. Seeing the tumor shrink on the ultrasounds gave me confidence the treatment was working. Best of luck to your mom.
Posts.Title: Chemo or Surgery First? danlias melmcbee

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 03:44PM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi ladies!  I hope you don't mind me jumping in- but I'm on the same TC schedule and have been lurking for a few weeks.  It is so refreshing to read your very honest and heartfelt posts of support for each other.  Your posts today especially resonated with me.  Wave- I teared up reading your post comparing us to trees.  I too have lost my hair and am having a pretty tough time with it.  The tree analogy made perfect sense to me- and you're absolutely right.  Come spring, we will be ready to show off our shiny new leaves! Leesa- I can relate with your limiting the threads you read. For the first 2 months or so after dx, I wouldn't read anything that was not clinical information.  With everything swimming around in my head, I just couldn't.  At the time, I needed to focus on the medical info related to the disease in order to make treatment decisions. Now that I'm actively in treatment, I'm more willing to seek out experiences of others, but like you, I am very careful of what I read.  Everyone's experience can be different, so I try to arm myself with information, but not freak myself out in the process. Wild- I agree that unfortunately we are not the first, and won't be the last to walk this path.  Knowing that there are thousands of women and men who have taken on the bc beast and won gives me hope. I've always given everything 105% and this current situation is no different. Like you, I have no idea why this particular challenge is part of my life plan.  I'm not sure that I'll ever be glad it happened, I just pray that someday I will understand why it did. Here's hoping for minimal se's for all of us!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 08:52AM MadisoninMd wrote: Loulabell - So glad to hear you have been feeling well and out enjoying the weather!  We've had a crazy winter so far.  Snow and ice one day and 50 degrees the next!  Perhaps you saw my post about surgery post chemo.  My MO and BS gave me a choice to do chemo before or after surgery.  For a variety of reasons, I chose to do it first.   Bela - I agree with the others.  Throw everything we can at this so there are no regrets and no "I wonder if's" later.  CKK - Leesa and Heather are right.  We've got your back!  I know it doesn't help much in the moment, but know that we are here for you.  I hope tomorrow is a better day. Wave - Good point about seeing the world moving happily right along.  I've often thought the same thing.  Sometimes it seems like everyone is going about their normal world and here I am stuck in bc land.  I know that won't always be the case and hopefully at somepoint bc won't always be at the forefront of my mind but right now it stinks.  For now, I'm trying to remind myself to take it one day at a time.  My focusing on the day, the weeks and months will take care of themselves.  Enough days go by and I'll be one of those, trying to find my new normal.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 12:25AM MadisoninMd wrote: Checking in from the chair... all is well so far. Sending positive thoughts and healing vibes to all dec sisters!

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 11:45AM MadisoninMd wrote: Lisa- CONGRATS!  I am so very happy for you that the infusion part is now over.  I pray the se fairies are kind to you.  Your posts have always been so inspirational and I admire your strength!  Welcome to the other side - Robin and I have a seat saved especially for you!! Joyce- So glad you are feeling better!  We are counting the treatments with you!  Hang in there- you are almost there!! Annie - My thoughts will be with you tomorrow!  Praying for a smooth day for you!  Yes- I chewed ice during the T part of my infusion.  The taste buds are starting to go tonight- but they are usually back by Saturday.  I'm trying the olive oil trick this time - so I'm hoping they might be back before then. Wouldn't that be nice.  Thanks for the comment about my MO's statement.  He is such a doll.  His statement really brought tears to my eyes.  I really did luck out with an incredible MO.  I could tell he was guinely happy for my progress and that I had completed this part of the journey.  We have a bet now on how much my tumor will have shrunk when surgery gets here.  If he's right - it will have shrunk by 62%.  He's been right on so far- we'll see if he's right with this as well.  I'm secretly hoping for a little more- but I'll take a 62% reduction!  Well my friends- I'm off to bed.  Sleep well all. All my best, Madison

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 07:56AM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi ladies!  I'm finally starting to emerge on the other side of the steriod crash.  Ugh those are nasty! The bone pain has settled in the past few days as well unfortunately.  I do feel a little better today after lots of sleep and a couple pain pills.  It will be a low key weekend for me as I try to regroup for next week.  HeatherW - CONGRATS!!  I am so happy that you are through this part of your treatment!  And to do 6 of them- you my friend are an inspiration!  I hope the extra hydration is working to keep the se fairies away!   They seem to be overstaying their welcome this time around so maybe they'll be too tired from their visit with me and bypass you.  CKK - so sorry to hear about the blown veins.  That really stinks!  I hope you are feeling better now. I hope everyone is doing well. All my best, Madison

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 10:28AM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi ladies!  Interesting about the olive oil.  I'll have to give that a try.  I'm glad to hear swishing works because I'm not sure I could actually swallow it.   Day 10 of TC round 3 for me today.  Overall I feel okay, but the itchies have started tonight.  I haven't had them since a few days after the first round.  I blamed it then on the T, not sure what is this time around.   Hellloo benadryl!  Annie - I have to admit that I laughed when I read your comment about your filter.  I have said the exact same words!  I've never been one to hide what I'm feeling, but until recently my filter has kept me in check.  I'm hoping it's just on vacation somewhere with my hair and both will return in time! Loulabell - I love the sign idea! I agree with you, each day can be it's own adventure.  Feeling okay today does not guarantee a good day tomorrow.  So many ups and downs. Wave - Sorry round #2 has you feeling lousy. I struggle with the taste bud and icky mouth for the first week or so.  The only thing that remotely sounds appealing to me are Carnation Breakfast Essentials.  I think it's the coldness because goodness knows I can't actually taste anything. I'm now on day 10 of round 3 and I still have some hair.  I never buzzed it and although it is thin, it's not completely gone.  Same with body hair, sparse in places but not totally gone.  I've actually started to notice a bit of growth which was unexpected (but very much appreciated!).  Too bad it's not on my head.  :( Ckk - Exactly!  Where does one go with a conversation like that?  Heather - I too get the  "it's gone by so fast" or "you would never know you are going through chemo" comments.  Really?  I agree with you- this is tough!  Both physically and mentally.  Like you, I would love to think that some people just don't know what to say.  Love your thought that they are sending a silent prayer.  I will think of that the next time I'm in that situation.  I too am grateful to all of you for your honesty and candor.    All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 07:36AM MadisoninMd wrote: Hello ladies~  I hope this Friday finds you all well!  Just stopping by to check on everyone as I tie up some loose ends before my last treatment on Monday.  Wow- that seems strangely wonderful to say- last treatment.  At the beginning I never thought this day would ever come. As odd as it sounds, I'm looking forward to getting Monday over with so the hair watch can begin!  Glad to hear everyone is hanging in there!  Heatherw- love your words "Keep on boxing that cancer biatch, ladies!!  It's nearly down for the count now...and soon you will rise up victorious!!!"  We will defeat this beast! All my best, Madison

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 10:39AM MadisoninMd wrote:   Hi all!  I apologize I've been MIA for the past couple of days as I just needed a break from everything bc related after I found out that a good friend completely violated my trust.  While the details aren't important, she knew how I felt about a particular situation and chose to completely disregarded it.  I feel angry and betrayed.  Although I did consider her a good friend, the trust is now gone.  For me, once that is gone, it is very hard to get it back.  Our friendship has been changed by this situation.  In time, I may be able to be around her, but I doubt I will ever trust her again.  The lesson learned here is that if people will gossip to you about others, they will gossip about you.  She was always telling me this and that about people we both knew but always said "Don't tell them I told you".  I never did as I felt I shouldn't know in the first place and it wasn't my news to spread.  I should have known...   Anyway, I've read through everyone's post and glad to hear everyone is hanging in there.  Kudos to those who crossed the infusion finish line last week.  I hope the se's are minimal and you are well on the road to feeling better!  As Lisa stated, it is a pretty incredible feeling knowing that there aren't any more chemo treatments in my future (hopefully forever!!).  My lumpectomy is scheduled for the end of the month so now my anxiety has shifted to that.  Ugh... always something.  All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2012 05:13PM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi ladies!  Rachel - Wow- what an adventurous couple of days!  I hope the olive oil is doing the trick and the thrush calms down for you! ckk- Will be thinking about you tomorrow! Last one!! YIPEE!!  Karmil - Good for you with the exercise! I am looking forward to getting back to it myself.  Right now the fatigue fairies have not left me.  I try to get in a little- but too much and it wipes me out for days. Annie - Have to say... sooo jealous of the hair growth but absolutely thrilled for you as well!  I cannot WAIT to have some sort of hair back.  I said it before- and I'll say it again.  Chemo took my hair after 15 days; I think it's only fair that I get it back after 15 days! Lisa - So sorry to hear about the fatigue.  I can certainly relate!  I too have had way more fatigue since finishing chemo than I ever did during treatment.  I've read where the effects are cumulative, but I have to wonder if part of it for me is also the mental let down of completing this portion of my treatment.  For 2 months, I stood ready to combat any se with every pill, comfort food and antidote imaginable.  Now that a few weeks have past since my last treatment, I've let my guard down so to speak.  I think my brain (and body really) are finally realizing that there really are no more infusions and are now starting to relax.  I keep telling myself that this too shall pass.  Easier to believe some days than others; but I'm trying. All in all I'm feeling okay although I'm still battling fatigue and some body aches.  Today I have been incredibly thirsty for some odd reason. I've had over 100 oz of water and still feel dry as the desert.  Thanks again Taxotere!  I hope this "gift" passes quickly because all of the trips to the little girls room are getting old!  I guess that one way to get a little exercise in though.  I've been fighting the desire to visit the "bitch and moan" club today.  I'm just having one of those I'm sick of all of this crap days.  I bought a new book this afternoon so I'm headed to read for a little while and then to bed.  Wishing everyone a wonderful evening and peaceful dreams. All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

All my best, Madison

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 05:19AM MadisoninMd wrote: Wave- not a chance!  We are all in this together and even though there are a few of us having our last treatment this week- we would never leave any of our fellow December sisters!  We will be back to cheer you guys on, give you hope that treatments will come to an end and offer words of support when those down days come.  Robin - sorry to hear #3 still has you down.  Sending healing vibes your way!  Becky - I hear ya with the "you're halfway there" and "only one more to go"!  It's true they think of infusion day only.  They have no idea about the anxiety of the days following waiting for se's to show up, the crash off of the steriods or dealing with the mounting fatigue.  You're absolutely right- it f-ing sucks!  I've gotten to the point where when someone asks me how I'm doing I just say "ok".  Because really- what are they going to do anyway?  I've had enough "I'm sorry's" and "hope you feel better".  I doubt they want to hear me launch into how much this sucks or how much I hate waking up every morning not knowing what se's will show up that day.  I know it comes from a place of concern, but I'm tired of talking about every ache and pain. Heatherb - Very touching that your family completed the walk in your honor! Gracie - I'll join you in the sick and tired club!  I'm looking forward to having this part of the journey over, but not looking forward to the days following.  This has been such a roller coaster ride. Annie - Thanks for the Egyptian Magic tip!  I will be starting rads sometime in March but I could use it now. (Thanks T for the crazy dry skin) All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 10:47AM - edited Feb 1, 2012 10:47AM by MadisoninMd Thanks ladies for the kudos but Rachel and Heather W are our resident rock stars!  I had 4 TC treatment- Rachel and Heather W are our superhero's with 6.  They are truly an inspiration!  I see I have a few posts to catch up on so I'm sure I'll have more comments in a bit.   Day 2 of round 4 has been pretty uneventful.  I was very busy at work so it made the day go by very quickly!  I had a follow up appt with my MO this afternoon and he was very happy with my progress and gave me several high-five's!  He was grinning from ear to ear and was genuinely exited about my progress.  He also told me that he would love for me to speak to some of his other patients.  He thought I could give them hope.  I almost teared up when he said it.  I told him to give me a few month to finish active treatment and decompress a bit, but then absolutely.  If I can help another patient through this hell by giving them hope and enouragement, then I'm all for it. I can feel my taste buds on the way out - but I've been trying the olive oil trick this time so hopefully that will work a little.  I've also been really good about my water today.  I told my MO about my increased bone pain with the last cycle and admitted I slacked on the water a bit last time because it tasted so bad.  He said that T can cause that but said keeping hydrated with lots of water really does help.  Thank goodness the flavor packets help because that's the only thing that makes water appealing right now. I hope all are doing well. Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 06:14PM MadisoninMd wrote: Mom- great story!  Cooper's reaction was too cute!  It's amazing how some people just go on and on isn't it?  I had something similar happen at work.  A few days after I started with my new 'do, a coworker stopped by and was raving about my new haircut.  Same questions and comments as the lady who cut your son's hair.  Eventually she says "If I didn't know better, I'd think you were wearing a cute wig!"   What makes it funnier is that none of my coworkers know of my diagnosis, treatment plan or lack of hair.  I wanted to crawl in a hole.  I just kept thinking to myself "Shut up... just please shut up!"  Finally she walked away- I've avoided her like the plague ever since!  I've said it before and I'll said it again- having bc is not for the faint at heart!

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 06:57PM MadisoninMd wrote: Annie- Great point!  I thought about that while my nurse was hanging my meds last week.  I wondered how many have gone through it before me for the docs to know what combination of drugs, steriods and anti-nauseau meds to give me to make this journey doable.  I will always be grateful for those who have walked the path before and paved the way.  I can only hope that my docs and/or the researchers learn something from my experience to brighten the path a little more for the next warrior.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 07:52PM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi all!  I hope everyone is having a restful, SE-free weekend!  Thankfully my bone aches have subsided and I feel pretty good.  Gearing up for my last treatment on the 30th.  I really am ready to put this part of the journey in the rear-view mirror.   I'll get a few weeks rest and recovery time and then surgery is scheduled for the end of February.   Just taking it one day at a time.  Leesa- WOW- scary about the toes!  I hope it was just the cold and that they are feeling much better now. Gracie - I never had a onco test done but my MO recommended TC instead of ACT because of my negative nodes.  He calls it "chemo light".  Not sure I would call this experience "light" but anyway.. He also said that he felt in my case ACT would be over treating me and he had serious ethical reservations about doing that. Bailey- Your Panera story gave me chills.  How incredible!  A reminder that God puts people in our path that we need, when we need them. Erica - Glad to hear that your first treatment went well!  I can understand the feeling of sadness that others are going through this same mess as I often feel the same.  I only hope that I can pass on my experience and knowledge gained and that it will in some way bring comfort and possibly hope to someone else. Rachel - I hope you had a fabulous birthday and treated yourself to something wonderful. I can understand about not feeling up to celebrating.  I felt the exact same over Christmas and New Year's.  I just wasn't in the mood.  Hopefully next year when all of this mess is behind us, we'll feel more celebratory. Josie - So far my brows and lashes are hanging in there.  My chemo teaching nurse told me that she didn't think I'd lose them completely, only that they might thin.  I'm not exactly sure what the reasoning was for her prediction.  I haven't noticed any thinning as of yet.  Keeping my fingers crossed they stay put!  Not brow or lashes- but I've started noticing some hair growth!  Too bad it's not on my head- but I'll take what I can get for now.  It is encouraging to see though. Heather - I think we're due for our last treatment on the same day.  Jan 30th?  It's hard to believe that we're just about a week away from our last one.  In November when this mess started- I didn't think this time would ever come.  Amazing what we, and our bodies, have been through in three short months. Wishing everyone a wonderful week! All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Wave & Lisa - My thoughts and prayers will be with you tomorrow! Can't wait to have all of my fellow Dec sisters on this side of chemo-hell!  Robin and I will have seats ready for everyone! All my best, Madison

I hope all are doing well - I see I have lots of posts to catch up on! All my best, Madison

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 06:49AM MadisoninMd wrote: Hi all!  Sorry I haven't posted here in a while... I seem to be hanging out on our fb page more often these days.  I did read through the last several pages and am glad to see everyone is hanging in there.  I am so happy for some of you that are finishing up rads.  One more thing to check off the list!  I'm also grateful that I'm not alone in the "just starting rads" club (sorry you're here with me Erica).  Slowly but surely- we are all making it through our active treatments and getting ever closer to that "new normal" they keep telling us about.  Bailey- mine disappeared as well about 8/9 weeks PFC (I'm 11 weeks PFC now).  Thankfully they did grow back rather quickly.  You would never know my brows are "new" and my lashes are definitely thinner than they were, but are still there and not noticeable to anyone unless I mention it.  (I don't though- I'm in the "if I don't say anything, maybe they won't notice" club! lol) Erica- I have my bottle of Tamoxifen all ready to go.  My MO gave me the script for it, but wanted me to get the blessing of my RO before I actually started taking it.  My RO wants me to wait until rads are complete before starting.  (At the rate I'm going with rads- it will be a long while before I start Tamox.  Ugh)  I am currently taking a multivitamin, a biotin supplement and caltrate (vitamin d/calcium).  My RO was fine with me continuing with all during rads. Momof3boys- <Fingers crossed> all goes well and your May 1st end rads date!  I'm thinking that's going to be my rads "start" date.  lol.. Melrose - Welcome to the group!  This is a fabulous group of ladies!!  You will definitely find support, encouragement, and yes, even a few laughs here.  As a few others have said, chemo is absolutely doable.  Just take it one treatment/one day at a time and before you know it, they will all be in the rear view mirror!  I was glad to read you have joined a thread of other April chemo gals.  The support and camaraderie of those on the chemo train with you is invaluable. I really don't know what I would have done without these ladies! All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

There you will meet ladies on your same schedule and will be going through it at the same time. It has been an invaluable part of my journey to be able to connect with others going through the same thing at the same time. Feel free to post any questions or pm me if would like. All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) chemo Neli Lumpynme

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 04:55PM MadisoninMd wrote: Neli,     I absolutely understand (as we all can) the fears about side effects from chemo.  The unknown, for me anyway, was the worst part.  I will share my experience with you, but please keep in mind, everyone reacts differently to treatment.  Even the ones of us on the same treatment regimen, TC.  The side effects range and not everyone experiences all of them, or even to the same extent.  Unfortunately, it's sort of a waiting game to see how you will respond.  Please take comfort in knowing that it is doable.  There are many of us who have been there, felt the same as you are right now, and have emerged on the other side.  This site is full of very wise, knowledgable, funny, understanding and compassionate women.  We will help support you through this!     That being said, my experience with TC has been very manageable. I am less than a week away from my last of 4 treatments. I've worked full time since the beginning (including treatment days). I have never <knock on wood> felt even a twinge of nausea, no vomiting, no fingernail issues, etc.      The only things I've noticed are body aches (similar to flu aches- but just in my lower legs) that last about 3 days, drier skin than normal, the loss of taste buds for the first couple of days (like you've burnt your tongue on something too hot - but it's your whole mouth), loss of hair on my head and fatigue. My eyebrows and lashes have stayed put.  The fatigue is annoying at times- but it is also doable.  I find it is more noticeable the first week after treatment.  My treatments are on Monday and usually by Saturday afternoon I've turned the corner and feel pretty good for the next 2 weeks.  The one thing I do the weekend before treatment is make sure I've cleaned the house, caught up on laundry, ran all of those little errands etc.  That way, for the entire week, I can just relax and take care of myself.  It seems to help me knowing that there isn't dry cleaning to pick up, stamps to buy etc.  I do have friends and family that would help me out with those things, but it has been really important to me to keep things as normal as I possibly can.  Doing those little things for myself keeps that sense of normalcy in my life.  I have noticed a bit of chemo brain- but I don't think it's really noticable to anyone but me.  I've noticed that I'm a bit more forgetful and sometimes words don't come to me as quickly.  I think part of it's the drugs, but I do believe the other is just the overload my brain has been on since diagnosis.  At first I was beginning to think it would never stop spinning.  Once some of the unknowns were eliminated, things really did calm down.  I hope this helps in some way. Feel free to post (or pm me) any questions or concerns, no matter what they are.  If I can't answer, there are loads of ladies here that are always more than willing to help a fellow sister.  All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) chemo Neli Lumpynme

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 04:43PM MadisoninMd wrote: Neli,    I'm glad I could help!  It can be very overwhelming (and scary!) reading about all of the side effects.  I was very scared before treatment started.  I remember saying a few times, even walking into the first appointment, that I didn't want to do it.  But, I put one foot in front of the other and kept walking, muttering the whole way.  I didn't want to do it, but I knew it was important for my long term health.  I kept reminding myself to focus on one day at a time.     The actual treatment was pretty boring.  Once they got me hooked up to the IV, the only real excitement I had was walking back and forth to the bathroom.  The first couple of days were a little anxious as I waited to see if any se's would show up.  To my relief, the ones that did show up were manageable.  One tip I picked up from this site that has been very helpful is to make sure you are well hydrated leading up to treatment day, the day of and the few days after.  When you think you've had enough water, drink some more.  It really does help.  If your taste buds go and water tastes bleck, try some of those flavor packets for your water.   I found lemonade (or any variation of lemonade) to taste great!  Actually, I just bought some more for my last treatment next week. The other thing that I have read on this site that has helped ladies during treatment week is to cook a few meals and freeze them.  That way on those nights that you just don't feel like cooking you can just pull something out of the freezer and warm up.   For me, being prepared for the things I can anticipate (running errands, having laundry caught up, meals in the freezer etc) before treatment allows me to mentally prepare for the things I can't anticipate should they happen.  That way if I'm not feeling up to those tasks in the few days after treatment, I don't have to worry about it.  I can just take it easy and focus on feeling better.  Hang in there and know that we are all here to support you through this! All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) chemo Neli Lumpynme

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 05:54PM MadisoninMd wrote: AnnTop,      You are very welcome!  I am so glad sharing my story helped you!  I was very worried and downright scared going into my first treatment but I kept reminding myself of something I read on bco.  It said "you don't have to be brave, you just have to show up".  (My apologies to the author- I don't remember who said it to give credit - but kudos to you!  That sums it up perfectly.)  That first day I wasn't feeling very brave - so I just showed up.  Hang in there as you go through treatment.  I'm just about at the end of this part of the journey, but I made it and so will you!  Just take it one day at a time and know that you are not alone.  The women here are amazing!  We are all in this together and we really do understand how you are feeling. All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) chemo Neli Lumpynme

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 05:07PM MadisoninMd wrote: Count me in the sick and tired club!  I'm on day 8 of round 3 of TC (one more to go!).  Thankfully I've only had the burnt mouth, bone pain and fatigue this time around.  The bone pain only lasted a day or two with the first two rounds- but this time it decided to visit for 4 days so far.  No Neulesta shot so I'm chalking it up to the T.   Might have to dig out some of those vicoden left over from SNB.  Enough is enough. Glad to read everyone is hanging in there.  Sending healing vibes to those who experiencing symptoms.. and enjoy the day vibes to those feeling normal!  Hang in there ladies- we are making our way through this.. one step and one day at a time. Like others have said, I am very grateful to have a place to connect with others experiencing the same hell I am.  As much as my friends and family want to understand, they just can't.  Granted, I don't even understand it all sometimes.  It's nice to be able to come here and see that I'm not alone in some of my feelings and fears. All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 09:42PM MadisoninMd wrote: Good morning ladies!  Headed to my last treatment today!  Glad to have this part of the journey behind me but feeling anxious as to what lies ahead this week.  Wishing all of you strength, peace and love. All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 07:40AM - edited Jan 31, 2012 07:56AM by MadisoninMd Thank you all for the prayers and well wishes!  All went well with today's last infusion.  (Boy it feels good to type that!)  I'm hydrating like a mad woman and praying the se's stay away!  I had more bone pain the last time around so I'm hoping with more hydration, more frequent walks, pain pills and a little good luck- they will stay away this time.  Time will tell.  Today was pretty emotional for me.  It was an incredible feeling to walk out of the infusion center for the last time.  My nurse made me promise to come visit when I was in the area.  I told her I would.  She told me she was proud of me and hugged me twice.  I have been truly blessed with very caring providers (docs and nurses), supportive friends and family and all of you incredible ladies on bco.  There have been many times that I've felt down, dreading an upcoming treatment, or just plain sick and tired and I've come here and someone always says something to lift my spirits.  It's not always something said directly to me, but just reading how we all support and encourage each other is truly heart warming.  You guys "get it" like no one else does.   Reading your posts is very comforting.  It's nice to know that I'm not alone in this club that no one wants to join- even though sometimes it does feel that way. Erica- Yuck about the fever!  Glad to hear the antibiotics are helping some.  Sending healing vibes your way.  Can't wait to see the superhero dude your friend came up with. Lisa - Glad to hear you had a quiet, and hopefully restful weekend.  It's a big milestone for you tomorrow.  Although the chemo journey doesn't quite end tomorrow (thanks again se's) it does mark a significant point in your journey.  I hope you celebrate and treat yourself to something wonderful!  I had lunch with the family and am thinking about a massage next week after the aches subside. Heather W - It's true... I've found strength throughout this journey that I didn't know I had.  I already have made plans of how I can use this strength for good once this little adventure is behind me.  Time to make some changes that are long overdue!  If I can make it through this little bit of hell~ I can handle anything!  Sending healing and positive vibes to my fellow Dec sisters! All my best, Madison
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2012 01:57AM MadisoninMd wrote: Thanks all for your kind words. This situation has definitely forced me to seriously consider who I call my friends. It just really upsets me because I would NEVER do that to a friend and I don't expect it from them either. Bc has really shown me who my friends are.. and who they are not.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 04:33PM MadisoninMd wrote: Neli - There are monthly threads under the "chemo" heading that are specific by month.  I'm not sure when you are starting (Jan or Feb) but there is a Jan group established and I'm sure there will be a February one started soon (if it's not out there already and I missed it).  Ladies on the same treatment schedule will post to the same thread (although others are always welcome!). Its nice to share and keep up with others who are on the same schedule.  If you haven't already- take a peek at the Dec or Jan threads.  There are awesome ladies there who can provide lots of guidance and support.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 11:34AM MadisoninMd wrote: Thanks ladies!  I'm leaving for my treatment in a few minutes.  One treatment and one day at a time right?  I'm praying the se's stay away!!  Halfway there after today!!! I recall reading on another thread (author please forgive me- I forgot where I read it to give proper credit) that as a patient she was told by a nurse that she (the nurse) prays for each bc patient that they have a "swift and safe journey through this hell".  I've thought about that statement ever since I read it.  What a perfect sentiment.
Posts.Title: Does the nervousness ever go away? MadisoninMd MadisoninMd

Posts.Content: MadisoninMd wrote: Hi everyone!  I've been lurking on bco since my diagnosis and have learned a great deal.  As many have said, it's not a club anyone wants to join. I am currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemo.  My second of four TC treatments is scheduled for tomorrow.  Question is- does the nervousness before treatment ever go away?  Granted I'm not as terrified as I was three weeks ago, but I've still been a nervous wreck all day.   My first treatment was relatively non-eventful with only mild se's (burnt mouth, hair loss, itchiness for 2 days).  I think I'm scared that won't continue.  Any words of wisdom? Dx 10/7/2011, IDC, 3cm, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Does the nervousness ever go away? MadisoninMd MadisoninMd
